title: Print, Design for the Ten-Deck House, June 16, 1928
medium: Mimeograph print, brush and blue watercolor on white wove paper
provenance: R. Buckminster Fuller; Max Protetch Gallery, New York City; 1991: acquired by Museum
creditline: Museum purchase from Smithsonian Institution Collections Acquisition Program Fund
description: Multi-leveled tower-like building supported by cables being dropped into bombed craters depicted in a dynamic and vigorous swooping, diagonal orientation from the upper left to lower right.  Three binder holes along left edge.
gallery_text: R. Buckminster Fuller was a designer, inventor, architect, engineer, and philosopher but he called himself simply a "comprehensivist." As an optimistic visionary, in 1927 Fuller decided to learn what one individual could do for humanity, considering global, economic, and environmental problems that were then rarely discussed. He designed for future rather than present needs, which is epitomized in the Ten-Deck House, one of his earliest designs for low-cost, mass-produced housing. To install the house, a small bomb would detonate, creating a crater. Then, a dirigible would deliver and lower the pre-constructed house, made of lightweight materials, into the hole. The entire building was structured around a central mast with tension cables that supported the decks, freeing the ground space. Each deck accommodated four living stories. This hand-colored mimeograph print, created using an early version of a photocopying machine, depicts the house from an angle, giving it the look of a skyscraper. Fuller was uninterested in aesthetics and traditional norms, so this image is likely the result of a functional idea, rather than a predetermined visual effort. Although the Ten-Deck House was never realized, he applied its principles to later designs, like the well-known single-family Dymaxion House, for which he created a prototype.
label_text: Fuller’s Ten-Deck House, composed of ten geometrically shaped floors, was designed to be mass-produced for single-family housing but was never realized. His lightweight aluminum structure was intended to be airlifted by zeppelin and lowered into a crater. Fuller produced low-cost multiples of his drawing using a mimeograph and hand-coloring the prints.

tombstone.epitaph:
Print, Design for the Ten-Deck House, June 16, 1928. Mimeograph print, brush and blue watercolor on white wove paper. 
Museum purchase from Smithsonian Institution Collections Acquisition Program Fund. 1991-53-1
